ygData.subject: Re: Speciation and Genome Clusters in the Encoding Space
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, I finally got around to reading through your long post reasoning about speciation techniques.  I appreciate the overview of pros and cons of several

Colin, I finally got around to reading through your long post
reasoning abo=
ut speciation techniques.  I appreciate the overview of
pros and cons of se=
veral different approaches.  I am interested to see
what a k-means type of =
speciation looks like, and also how anchored
vs. un-anchored  dynamics woul=
d differ in practice.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <col=
in.green1@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> Thanks for the feedback so far. Ther=
e are a few issues raised and I'll
> try to cover all of them. Apologies fo=
r the length of the post.
> 
> Firstly I did of course mean tabu search - e=
asily confused terms I
> think you'll agree.
> 
> Some general themes then:=

> 
> 1) Speciating by comparing new genomes (I call them offspring from
> =
here) with each species in turn.
> 
> Generally I like this, but there are =
some potential side effects I'm
> unsure about. e.g. if the species overlap=
 in the encoding space then
> any offspring that exist in an overlapping re=
gion will always get
> assigned to the species that comes first, this leave=
s an empty bite
> shaped region (a crecent shape in 2D space) in the second=
 species.
> Ultimately you might end up where the two regions are almost ex=
actly
> the same (the exemplars are very close) and so the genomes in the
>=
 second species are all in a very thin cresent formation. In fact you
> mig=
ht have several species where each one is a cresent shape on the
> edge of =
the previous one.
> 
> This in turn might affect some of our other mechanis=
ms. e.g. if
> species number 2's genomes are as fit as number 1's then we e=
xpect
> them to contain about the same number of genomes (through fitness
>=
 sharing), but in fact most of species 2's offspring end up in the
> first =
species. Later on (in sharpneat at least) we might take N% of
> the best ge=
nomes in each species as the parents for the next
> generation, but because=
 the total number in each species has been
> distorted, that N% is similarl=
y distorted - thus species 2 is
> potentially (depending how you make the c=
alculations)
> under-represented as a parent for the next generation of off=
spring.
> 
> The explicit clustering algorithm I described is in fact calle=
d
> k-means clustering. So if we use k-means (or some other standard
> appr=
oach) as a way of dividing our genomes into clusters before we
> start the =
main NEAT loop running we lessen the problem of overlapping
> regions betwe=
en species. We can still use the same speciation
> technique in the main lo=
op and perhaps periodically re-speciate using
> k-means if we think overlap=
 is occuring, if there is some easy way of
> detecting the amount of overla=
p.
> 
> 2) In sharpneat v1 I actually test offspring against their parent
>=
 species first (note. there are two parent species in cross species
> breed=
ing, but normally only one), and *then* test against every other
> species =
in turn. I didn't properly consider what this means when I
> wrote the code=
. Firstly it means performance is improved because most
> offspring will in=
 fact be placed in their parent's species, thus no
> further comparisons ar=
e necessary. However it introduces the
> possibility (likelihood?) of speci=
es overlapping to a large degree,
> they could even represent the exact sam=
e region in the encoding space.
> Ultimately they may drift apart but in th=
e mean time they are both
> searching the same fitness space which is preci=
sely what speciation is
> trying to avoid.  Potentially all species could a=
ll get stuck on some
> local maximum (=3D bad).
> 
> 
> So at this point a =
better strategy than both mine and Ken's is to use
> Ken's approach of comp=
aring species in turn (with the species in a
> fixed order between generati=
ons) but to avoid cresent shaped species
> (if indeed that is what happens)=
 by using k-means at the outset and
> periodically, e.g. when the species c=
ount goes outside of some limits
> or every N generations.
> 
> 3) Petar, r=
egarding your suggestion about creating a representative
> genome for each =
species. This is potentially equivalent to calculating
> the center center =
of the region in space defined by the genomes, in
> fact if you average the=
 weight of connections with the same ID you
> calculate the center of mass =
of the genomes. So in 2D the exemplar is
> currently in the center of a cir=
cle, but the bulk of the other genomes
> may be clustered around one edge o=
f the circle (because of some local
> maximum say), thus the center of 'mas=
s' is in fact not in the center
> but somewhere towards (or within) the clu=
ster. So ff we did anchor our
> species for their lifetime this would becom=
e far more likely.
> 
> BTW this center of mass of genomes is effectively w=
hat k-means
> clustering is doing, we calculate the average distance from e=
ach
> genome in a cluster; for each cluster; and assign a genome to the
> c=
luster it is nearest to - that is, it gets assigned to the cluster
> whose =
*center of mass* is closest. We could calculate the center of
> mass direct=
ly to reduce the number of comparisons we make, but there
> are some reason=
s not to - (A) Whenever we re-assign a genome from one
> cluster to another=
 we move the center of mass of both of those
> clusters, thus they would ne=
ed recalculating (although you could avoid
> recalculating right way). And =
(B) Calculating the center of mass
> requires us to to define a coordinate =
system, which admitedly would be
> easy, it's just an array of numbers. But=
 it's even easier to plug in a
> function that take two genomes and returns=
 the distance between them
> as a single number. The function effectively d=
efines a distance metric
> and we can plug in and try alternative distance =
metrics (euclidean,
> manhattan, kens original [I'm calling it ken's canoni=
cal distance
> metric :) ] )
> 
> 4) Anchoring of species. I think if we we=
re to try tabu search we
> would need to anchor the species. Otherwise if a=
 species drifts then
> we have only partially searched some regions and we =
need some means of
> recording that information. What you end of with is a =
sort of density
> map of the search space where density represents how much=
 searching
> has occured in a given region. It's just a lot simpler if the =
search
> regions are fixed/distinct chunks of space that we flag as being
>=
 search or not searched (not exhaustively searched, but enough that we
> de=
cided to move on). There is still a problem in that as the compat.
> thresh=
old varies the radius of each species/region is changing - so
> they're not=
 actually fixed chunks but varying in size.
> 
> I can see the pros of allo=
wing species to drift; following the species
> champ. But maybe it's not so=
 bad to acnhor. What might happen is that
> as genome smove towards some fi=
tter space they end up on the edge of
> the species/region they are in. Now=
 their offspring are outside the
> region, they form a new species because =
they are not close enough to
> an existing one.  If we now re-speciate usin=
g k-means (rather than the
> current approach of increasing the compat. thr=
eshold) then the new/fit
> cluster will form a new species with a new ancho=
r, the old
> species/regions are thrown away completely. 
> 
> The idea nee=
ds a bit of work/thought but I think it might work. So in
> conclusion k-me=
ans clustering potentially gives you less species
> overlap (in sharpneat's=
 case) or less cresent shaped species with a
> distorted size relative to t=
heir fitness (in Ken's case). And along
> with anchored species exemplars i=
t gives you an easy(er) way if doing
> tabu search.
> 
> Colin.
>
